channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.dc:creator: The Age's View
item.description: The proposed introduction of laws to ban religious schools from sacking or refusing to employ teachers because of their sexuality or gender identity is welcome.
item.title: Religious schools discrimination law update merits bipartisan support

item.dc:creator: Nick Galvin
item.description: While artists everywhere are suffering due to the lockdown, Bridie O’Brien has made a startling success returning to her first love.
item.title: When COVID-19 struck, Bridie followed her art

item.dc:creator: Jake Niall
item.description: Growing maturity and a competitive edge have helped Western Bulldogs tall Josh Schache reignite his career at AFL level as he prepares for his first grand final.
item.title: Learning to compete: The redemption of Josh Schache

item.dc:creator: Lucy Manly
item.description: It’s been quite a week for the family of Australian basketball sensation Ben Simmons who is in the midst of a trade war as his younger sister is banned from publishing false allegations against his half-brother.
item.title: From basketball to court, Ben Simmons’ week of family drama

item.dc:creator: Jon Faine
item.description: It is beyond satire that a politician who introduced laws demanding greater transparency for political donations accepts an anonymous donation himself.
item.title: The problems with Porter

item.dc:creator: Robert Moran
item.description: Amazon’s remarkably fun The Voyeurs relaunches a classic film genre that peaked in the ’90s.
item.title: Erotic potential: Streaming era reheats forgotten genre of sexual desire

item.description: If you’re planning to sell your home, then perhaps those bright yellow tiles you just fell in love with are ill-advised. But if it’s your forever home, I say go for it.
item.title: Neale Whitaker’s design advice to turn your house into a home

item.dc:creator: Sam Phillips
item.description: Several Australians starred against the Springboks on Saturday night, but who stood up when the match was there to be won?
item.title: Player ratings: The Wallabies who led the charge to No.3 world ranking

item.dc:creator: Danny Weidler
item.description: A lot of difficult stories have come out of the Bulldogs camp this year, but none compare to what Tuipulotu Katoa is going through.
item.title: Brain aneurysm, staph infection and heart murmur turn young gun’s life upside down

item.dc:creator: Tony Wright
item.description: The Australian-French friendship was created in blood. With France now the European leader, the consequences of a falling-out could prove very injurious.
item.title: ‘Do not forget Australia’: Morrison must hope an old friendship holds

item.dc:creator: Jordan Baker
item.description: Schools are grappling with fiery divisions among parents about whether students should be back at school, with some calling for remote learning until the end of the year.
item.title: Some parents demand a return to class, others want to keep their kids at home

item.dc:creator: Parnell Palme McGuinness
item.description: Helping those who are suffering from poor mental health will require us to emphasise resilience rather than illness.
item.title: Let’s not panic about the mental health harms of the pandemic

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: Lockdown has hammered Sydney’s restaurants and bars, but Luke Mangan says the city will boom once lockdown eases.
item.title: ‘Itching to get out’: Luke Mangan prepares for Sydney to boom once lockdown ends

item.dc:creator: Jacqueline Maley
item.description: The factions control much in the major parties, but it may take the rise of political outsiders to achieve a more representative Australian democracy.
item.title: Keneally, Steggall and the political outsiders

item.dc:creator: James Massola
item.description: Until Labor’s NSW Right faction can set aside disputes like this and focus on the swathe of seats on offer across Sydney, then the ALP’s path to victory is narrow.
item.title: Labor’s fight over Fowler is about a lot more than Kristina Keneally

item.dc:creator: Christian Nicolussi
item.description: Keaon Koloamatangi won 10 straight rugby league titles as a kid, as well as swimming and surf lifesaving titles, but knows the sweetest trophy of all awaits.
item.title: The South Sydney sporting prodigy who didn’t know how to lose

item.dc:creator: Tony Wright
item.description: Once, protesters would have stormed the streets. But in 2021, an Australian prime minister can commit to nuclear propulsion and the opposition will support him.
item.title: Australia’s fading anti-nuclear movement: a short history

item.dc:creator: Peter FitzSimons
item.description: NSW Nationals leader John Barilaro says rural realism is driving most of his MPs to vote for reform.
item.title: John Barilaro surprises on right-to-die law for NSW

item.dc:creator: Nick Bonyhady
item.description: Hairdressing salon owner Colin Moxey is afraid the government will make him work out his own COVID-19 vaccine policy for clients, instead of setting clear rules for all businesses.
item.title: Liberty from lockdowns or a two-speed society?

item.dc:creator: Phil Colgan
item.description: Our churches support emergency action during the pandemic. Longer term, the idea that Christians would exclude anyone from church is extremely problematic.
item.title: The word from a vaccinated preacher: we don’t urge law-breaking, but we cherish religious freedom

item.description: I’ve realised that all I really need is shelter, heating, my dog and my wok. The rest is icing. And I have never felt more liberated as a result.
item.title: I always dreamt of a bigger, better house. Lockdown changed that

item.description: Tragically, the Demons have lost five current or former players aged under 60 since the club last played in a grand final. Their families’ hearts still beat true.
item.title: Families of Demons who died too young say their hearts still beat true

item.dc:creator: Latika Bourke
item.description: Britain’s crowded beaches in June 2020 did not drive a surge in COVID cases, but experts say travelling to the beach in crammed cars and buses is high risk.
item.title: British statistics suggest beaches aren’t COVID superspreader hotspots

item.description: The US plans to speed up its efforts to expel Haitian migrants on flights to their Caribbean homeland, officials said on Saturday.
item.title: US ramps up plan to expel Haitian migrants gathered in Texas

item.description: Religious leaders argue that everyone has the right to worship in their churches regardless of vaccination status. What about the rights of those vaccinated people who will be harmed by possible exposure to the virus?
item.title: Have religious leaders forgotten the commandment ‘love thy neighbour’?

item.dc:creator: Sarah Keoghan
item.description: Sophie Dwyer had expected her first year in Super Netball to be a learning experience, but nothing like the journey that took her all the way to the grand final.
item.title: ‘I wasn’t at my best’: Dwyer has Diamonds in sight after unlikely breakout year

item.dc:creator: The Herald's View
item.description: With five weeks to go until kindergarten and year 1 are due back in the classroom, principals are grappling with parent communities that are increasingly divided over whether students should be vaccinated, and whether children should be back in the classroom at all.
item.title: Parents need more information to prepare for school return

item.description: Trivia buffs: test your knowledge with today's interactive superquiz and target.
item.title: Target Time and Superquiz, Sunday, September 19

item.dc:creator: Aisha Dow
item.description: Last year the typical coronavirus patient was older and might have come from a nursing home. This year they are much younger. And this is posing new challenges.
item.title: The face of the COVID pandemic has fundamentally changed in Victoria

item.dc:creator: Nathanael Cooper
item.description: From Ben and Jen’s highly staged red carpet re-debut, to Oscar Isaac eating Jessica Chastain’s arm, it seems celebrities have forgotten how to behave in public.
item.title: I’m no puritan but can the celebs please put the PDAs away

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: In what it describes as a “middle ground” position paper, the peak medical body broadly backs the Doherty Institute’s thresholds for reopening the country once 70 and 80 per cent of the population aged 16 and over is vaccinated.
item.title: Federal AMA backs reopening plan, no need to vaccinate kids first

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: There have been 144 COVID-positive inmates at the privately-run Parklea prison. Their family members on the outside are desperately trying to contact them.
item.title: One in ten Parklea prison inmates has COVID-19, unable to call relatives

item.dc:creator: Lucy Carroll
item.description: The number of twins and triplets born to women undergoing IVF has fallen to a record low over the past decade, while the live birth rate continues to climb particularly when using frozen embryos.
item.title: Unprecedented rise in IVF success rate, but multiple births fall to record low

item.description: A $365 million program designed to reduce landfill by turning food scraps into fertiliser has failed to gain a foothold beyond three councils in Sydney.
item.title: Household food waste program fails to catch on among Sydney councils

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: “It’s important that children do not spend all their holidays on devices,” said STEM education professor Garry Falloon.
item.title: How to make locked-down holidays different from locked-down learning

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: Boxing is increasing in popularity despite the closure of gyms during lockdown, with more women taking up the sport.
item.title: ‘It’s saved more people than it hurts’: The rising popularity of women’s boxing

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: Many children with chronic health conditions are unlikely to return to NSW classrooms this year, despite the Department of Education saying it won’t run a dual system.
item.title: ‘Not too much to ask’: The students who won’t return to school this year

item.dc:creator: Tom Cowie
item.description: On a surface level, next weekend’s AFL grand final would appear to pit supporter bases from two different walks of life against each other. In truth, both fan bases are probably more alike than many think.
item.title: Landlords v tenants? Jokes aside, Dees and Dogs fans share similarities

item.dc:creator: Linda Morris
item.description: Nearly half a million vouchers have been redeemed so far this year by parents to get their children creative.
item.title: Lockdown rush to use $100 Creative Kids vouchers

item.description: Free weekly horoscope for each star sign from renowned astrologer Hedy Damari. Forecasts for the week ahead in life, love and career.
item.title: Your Weekly Horoscope for September 19-26

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: Extreme positions on COVID-19 are still being staked out in the medical establishment, the academy and parts of the media.
item.title: Reopening, resistance and the long tail of ‘zero COVID’

item.dc:creator: Lucy Cormack
item.description: A man with stab wounds has been found on the side of a road in Sydney’s west after he was allegedly abducted.
item.title: Man allegedly abducted, dumped on road side with stab wounds

item.description: Afghanistan’s new Taliban rulers set up a ministry for the “propagation of virtue and the prevention of vice” in the building that once housed the Women’s Affairs Ministry, escorting out World Bank staffers on Saturday as part of the forced move.
item.title: Taliban replace ministry for women with one restricting them

item.description: Illustrations by the artist from The Age.
item.title: The latest illustrations from artist Matt Golding

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, September 19, 2021

item.dc:creator: Jack Latimore
item.description: Paul Cleary’s book Title Fight shows just how far we have to go before Native Title starts to benefit Indigenous communities in meaningful ways.
item.title: Victory in an unfair fight: Pilbara traditional owners v Fortescue

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, September 18, 2021

item.dc:creator: Jessica Irvine
item.description: I abhor the idea of taking a home from a young family who could otherwise buy it to live in. But if economics teaches us anything, it’s that incentives matter.
item.title: ‘I’d hate me, too’: Why I’ve decided to become a property investor

item.description: New Zealand warmed up for their 100th Test against South Africa by overtaking them as the world’s No.1 side.
item.title: All Blacks return to top of rankings after big win over Pumas

item.dc:creator: Nicole Pedersen-McKinnon
item.description: A 0 per cent balance transfer credit card gives you an opportunity to have every dollar you repay chip away at your principal, rather than going toward extortionate interest.
item.title: Credit cards that can save you more than $700 a year
